awd_titl_txt: Discovering the First Exoplanets Around White Dwarf Stars with the Zwicky Transient Facility
awd_abstract_narration:
Keaton Bell is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to conduct a program of research and education at the University of Washington.  He will use data from the Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF) to attempt to make the first discoveries of extrasolar planets (exoplanets) orbiting white dwarf (WD) stars --- collapsed stars, which are no longer producing energy from nuclear fusion like normal stars, but are glowing faintly from residual heat. Bell will determine what fraction of WDs host exoplanets, and study the populations of WD exoplanets, which will lead him to a better understanding of how planetary systems survive the collapse of their star. In conjunction with his research, he will mentor college freshman students from groups underrepresented in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields, and he will help train astronomy graduate students in methods of data science. 

The proposed scientific program seeks to characterize the properties of individual WD planetary systems and investigate the physical mechanisms that affect planets during post-main-sequence evolution. Bell proposes to identify candidate planet transits by searching the ZTF data set for statistically significant dips in measured flux. Strong candidates will be confirmed and characterized with follow-up photometric and spectroscopic observations. The educational component of his work will help promote a more capable and diverse STEM workforce by providing students with valuable skills in preparation for possible careers in science or engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Most stars, including our own, will end their lives as compact white dwarf stars. The properties of planets that orbit white dwarfs can inform our understanding of the fates of planets when their host stars die. These planets are extremely difficult to detect for practical reasons related to the small size of the Earth-sized white dwarf stars; however, brief moments when a planet orbits in front of and blocks out the white dwarf might be discoverable in a large enough data set. This project started with a database of one trillion measurements of star brightness obtained by the Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF), which were narrowed down to hundreds of thousands of white dwarfs before individual snapshots were identified where the white dwarfs appeared temporarily fainter than usual. We had to develop a framework for inspecting thousands of images by eye to ensure that the measurements corresponded to reliable data, because our search for atypical star brightness measurements unearthed a lot of bad data. The candidate planet systems were followed up with the 3.5-meter telescope at Apache Point Observatory, where we resolved the eclipse profiles and measured radial velocity variations to understand the nature of the transiting bodies. It appears that the dozen stars that we studied in detail are all eclipsing binaries, demonstrating that transiting planets are much less common than white dwarf eclipsing binaries. A publication is in preparation reporting the full catalog of eclipsing/transiting planets, and there is a planned PhD thesis in the works to characterize that entire sample, which is likely to contain the first exoplanet waiting to be discovered to orbit a white dwarf star.

The project achieved broader impacts primarily through mentoring of undergraduate students involved in individual research projects. Every fall quarter I mentored one or two freshman undergraduates from underrepresented backgrounds through the Pre-Majors in Astronomy Program (Pre-MAP) at the University of Washington. Work with two more senior students set them up to successfully transition into graduate programs. One of these students published their first first-author paper describing a methodology for identifying the source of brightness variations in images suffering from blended starlight, along with an open-source Python package as a resource for the research community (TESS-Localize). I served as an instructor for the 2021 ZTF Summer School, teaching an audience of primarily graduate students the techniques and pitfalls of time domain analysis of variable stars. My public outreach talks at Astronomy on Tap Seattle, Astronomy at Home (online), and the Seattle Science Slam shared the motivations and the results of the fellowship project with hundreds of members of the science-interested public.
